etymologies: late 19th century: probably American Spanish; compare with the sense ‘upheaval, disorder’, attested in Argentina, Paraguay, and Uruguay

definitions: a Caribbean style of dance music typically in duple and triple time, chiefly associated with Dominica and Haiti

examples.text: sounds of Latin music, mostly salsa and merengue, came in from the streets
there was a merengue band to keep the beat hot

definitions: a style of dancing associated with merengue music, with alternating long and short stiff-legged steps.
shortDefinitions: style of dancing associated with merengue, with alternating long and short stiff-legged steps
